intro: Phoradendron zacapanum, commonly known as the Zacapan mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant native to Central America. It belongs to the Viscaceae family and typically grows on the branches of host trees such as ceiba and mahogany. The plant has small, leathery leaves and produces white or pinkish flowers that are pollinated by insects. Its berries are red and contain seeds that are dispersed by birds. This species plays a role in the ecosystem by providing food for wildlife and contributing to the biodiversity of its habitat.
